docs.lead_paragraph: United Overseas Bank, Singapore's number three banking group, said Wednesday it would sell its Singapore life insurance unit to Prudential P.L.C. of Britain for 428 million Singapore dollars ($307 million), confirming an earlier report.

headline.main: Prudential Buys Singapore Bank's Insurance Unit

docs.abstract: United Overseas Bank, Singapore's number three banking group, said Wednesday it will sell its Singapore life insurance unit to Prudential for $307 million, confirming an earlier report.
docs.snippet: United Overseas Bank, Singapore's number three banking group, said Wednesday it will sell its Singapore life insurance unit to Prudential for $307 million, confirming an earlier report.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the embattled Connecticut Democrat who was facing an increasingly tough bid for a sixth term in the United States Senate, has decided not to seek re-election this year, Democrats familiar with his plans said Wednesday.

headline.main: Dodd Will Not Seek Re-election, Democrats Say

docs.abstract: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the embattled Connecticut Democrat who was facing an increasingly tough bid for a sixth term in the U.S. Senate, has decided not to seek re-election this year, Democrats familiar with his plans said Wednesday.

headline.main: Senator Dodd Will Not Seek Re-election, Democrats Say

docs.lead_paragraph: Grady Memorial Hospital, a public institution in Atlanta, has agreed to extend its payments for dialysis for about 50 dislocated patients, mostly illegal immigrants, at private clinics.

docs.lead_paragraph: Illegal, rarely prosecuted and rarely discussed, abortion has suddenly become a public issue in South Korea.

headline.main: South Korea Confronts Open Secret of Abortion

docs.lead_paragraph: C-Span, which has steered an apolitical course through countless political campaigns, has touched off a political tempest with a request to Congressional leaders to allow live television coverage of the endgame negotiations on health care legislation. In a letter written Dec. 30 and released on Tuesday, Brian Lamb, the chief executive of C-Span, asked Congressional leaders to ''allow the public full access, through television, to legislation that will affect the lives of every single American.''
docs.abstract: C-Span touches off political tempest with request to Congressional leaders to allow live television coverage of endgame negotiations on health care legislation; Republicans, known to have held secret sessions when they were in control, seize on request to highlight their complaints that Democrats have been making backroom sweetheart deals; Democrats counter that much of lengthy process has been open to cameras, and that Republicans were simply trying to torpedo legislation; photo (M)
docs.snippet: C-Span, which has steered an apolitical course through countless political campaigns, has touched off a political tempest with a request to Congressional leaders to allow live television coverage of the endgame negotiations on health care...

docs.lead_paragraph: Could a health care overhaul open the door to a raft of consumer lawsuits against insurers over denied medical claims? If more people sign up for health coverage through new health insurance exchanges, they are likely to have more leeway to sue than they do under today's employer-based plans.
docs.abstract: Research group Hastings Center suggests that if more people sign up for health coverage through proposed health insurance exchanges, they could have more leeway to sue than they do under employer-based plans; asserts that increase in lawsuits could drive up costs as insurers approve claims defensively to avoid litigation; experts say such scenario is unlikely (M)
docs.snippet: Could a health care overhaul open the door to a raft of consumer lawsuits against insurers over denied medical claims?      If more people sign up for health coverage through new health insurance exchanges, they are likely to have more leeway to sue...

docs.lead_paragraph: House Democratic leaders said on Tuesday that they would insist on changes in the Senate's health care legislation to make coverage more affordable for middle-class Americans and to tighten control over the insurance industry. But it remained unclear how much leverage the House would have in coming negotiations, given that Senate Democrats cannot spare a single vote without jeopardizing the bill's chances of passing.

headline.main: House Democrats Seek Changes in Senate Bill

docs.abstract: House Democratic leaders said on Tuesday that they would push for changes to the Senate health care legislation to make coverage more affordable and to tighten control over the insurance industry.
docs.snippet: House Democratic leaders said on Tuesday that they would push for changes to the Senate health care legislation to make coverage more affordable and to tighten control over the insurance industry.
